Chad--  Grassroots seems to be a way the program can grow.  Have past CA garduates recommend at least one other person who would benefit from the Academy, and send a letter out to them.  Speaking at civic meetings has worked very well for us in the past.

answers.author: Ricardo Morse
answers.text:
I would suggest you all consider targeted recruitment. Identify specific people and groups of people you would like to see attend and extend personal invitations (or have your mayor extend personal invitations). Other communities have done this with some success.

answers.author: Kirk Bednar
answers.text:
Brentwood, TN has citizen academies for police and fire.  Both have established alumni groups from prior years and these alumni are always great recruiters for future years.  Speaking at civic groups is also a good source especially if the group contains alumni and they talk it up.

author: Chad Quinn
text:
The City of Tamarac is going into the fifth year of it's Citizen Academy -- each year the number of applications we receive decreases even though our marketing efforts remain the same; and in many ways increase (social media outreach, etc.).
Has anyone experienced similar decreases?
Has anyone had success with reinvigorating their citizen academy?
Thank you,
Chad Quinn
